The commentary says:

Why is this?
All worldly beings are attached to the two views:
Existence or non-existence.
Those who follow the flow of birth and death are mostly attached to existence, while those who go against the flow of birth and death are mostly attached to non-existence;
Those with much attachment to the view of self are attached to existence, while those with much attachment to wrong views are attached to non-existence.
Furthermore, those with much attachment to the four views are attached to existence, while those with much attachment to wrong views are attached to non-existence.
Those with much of the two poisons (greed and anger) are attached to existence, while those with much ignorance are attached to non-existence.
Not knowing that the five aggregates arise from the convergence of causes and conditions, they are attached to existence. Not knowing the convergence, they are attached to non-existence.
Because of associating with bad friends and heretical scriptures, they fall into annihilationism and the view of no sin or merit. Those with the view of non-existence are attached to non-existence;

There are sentient beings who think everything is empty, and their minds are attached to this emptiness;

There are sentient beings who think all dharmas known by the six sense faculties exist, which is the view of existence.
Those with much craving are attached to the view of existence, while those with much views are attached to the view of non-existence.
Sentient beings are attached to the views of existence and non-existence in this way.
These two kinds of views are false and not real, and they destroy the middle way.
It is like a person walking on a narrow path, with deep water on one side and a great fire on the other, both of which will lead to death;

Why is this?
If all dharmas definitely truly exist, then there are no causes and conditions;

If there is a dharma that is truly existent, then there is neither good nor evil, neither bondage nor liberation, and also no various differences among dharmas.

Furthermore, those who hold the view of existence are in opposition to those who hold the view of non-existence. Because of this opposition, there is right and wrong. Because of right and wrong, there is dispute. Because of dispute, the afflictions arise. Because of the afflictions, karma is produced. Because karma is produced, the gates to the evil destinies are opened.
In the true nature, there is no opposition, no right or wrong, no disputes!
Furthermore, those who are attached to existence, if things are impermanent, then they give rise to sorrow and distress;
if they are attached to non-existence, they commit evil deeds and fall into hell after death to suffer.
Those who are not attached to existence or non-existence do not have these various faults;

Furthermore, it is not reasonable that these five aggregates are either permanent or impermanent.
Why is this?

If the five aggregates were permanent, there would be no arising and no ceasing. With no arising and no ceasing, there would be no good and evil, and no good and evil consequences. The world would be like nirvana, without any characteristics of destruction.
Who would believe such a lie?
We can see with our own eyes that when people die, they cry. This shows that sentient beings are impermanent.
Just as grass and trees wither, flowers and fruits decay, this shows that external things are impermanent.
When the great eon comes to an end, everything is destroyed. This is the great impermanence.
For these various reasons, the five aggregates cannot be said to be permanent.
Furthermore, impermanence destroys permanence. It is not appropriate to take impermanence as being so.
Why is this?
If the characteristics of all dharmas are impermanent, and they cease moment by moment, then the six sense faculties cannot grasp the six sense objects.
Why is this?

Because the inner mind and external objects are both without abiding, one should not be able to perceive, one should not be able to know, and there should also be no cultivation, causes, conditions, or karmic retribution!
Because there are many causes and conditions, the karmic retribution should also be many, and this should not be possible.
Moreover, one argues with the view of eternalism and the view of nihilism.
For these various reasons, the impermanence of the five aggregates cannot be attained.

Suffering and happiness, self and non-self, emptiness and reality, having characteristics and being without characteristics, having activity and being without activity, this meaning is as explained in various places above.

The cessation of the five aggregates means that because they arise from causes and conditions, they have no nature. Because they have no nature, they are quiescent. Because they are quiescent, they are like nirvana.

Because this bodhisattva's wisdom and merits are great, although the minds of the buddhas are impartial, it is the Dharma that they should think of this bodhisattva in order to encourage others.

[Sutra] Furthermore, Shariputra!
When bodhisattva-mahasattvas practice prajnaparamita, they do not think like this:
'There are dharmas that either combine or do not combine with dharmas, either the same or not the same.'
Why is this?
This bodhisattva-mahasattva does not see these dharmas either combining or not combining with other dharmas, either the same or not the same.
Shariputra!
Bodhisattva-mahasattvas should practice in this way, which is called being in accordance with prajnaparamita.
[Treatise] says:
All dharmas have no dharma that combines with other dharmas.
Why is this?
Because all dharmas have no part that combines.
For example, two fingers have four sides, and one side combines, while the other three sides do not combine;
Because they do not combine, why not call it non-combination?
Question:
Because there is a place of combination, it is called combination. Why say non-combination?
Answer:
The place of combination is not for the finger, it is for the parts of the finger;
It is only the parts of the finger, there is no further finger principle.
Because two fingers are close together, it is provisionally called combination, there is no further combination principle.
Furthermore, form, smell, taste, and touch are collectively called the finger;
Only touch has the power of combination, the other three do not combine.
For this reason, it cannot be said that the fingers combine.
Furthermore, like different categories in the same place, it is not called combination, because their characteristics are different;

The same is true for all dharmas. The characteristic of earth is in earth, the characteristic of water is in water, and the characteristic of fire is in fire. In this way, their natures are different, and it is not called combination.
For this reason, it is said that there is no dharma that combines with a dharma, whether in combination or not in combination.
Equality means that all phenomena have one characteristic, which is called equality.

Because they all have the characteristic of existence, the characteristic of impermanence, the characteristic of suffering, the characteristic of emptiness and non-self, and the characteristic of non-arising and non-cessation, and because the events are no different, it is called equality.
Inequality means that each has a separate characteristic.
Like the characteristics of form and formlessness, the characteristics of solidity and fluidity, these are each different and not the same, which is called inequality.
Bodhisattvas do not see equality or inequality.
Why is it so?

Because all phenomena are non-existent, their intrinsic nature is empty and non-existent, and because they are non-existent, they cannot be seen. Because they cannot be seen, there is no equality or inequality.
Equality and combination are associated with practice;
non-combination and inequality are not associated.
Question:

Following the dharma nature is good, not following the dharma nature is not good.

Bodhisattvas practice the emptiness of sentient beings and the emptiness of dharmas, deeply enter the characteristics of emptiness and unite with them, and remember their original vows to liberate sentient beings;
Seeing that sentient beings are deluded and inverted, they give rise to various attachments to empty things, and immediately give rise to a mind of great compassion:
Although I understand this matter, others do not.
In order to teach and transform them, they give rise to great kindness and great compassion.
They are also able to constantly avoid giving rise to things that destroy the six perfections.
Why is this?
Newly initiated bodhisattvas practice the six perfections, but because they are mixed with the six kinds of evil practices, the six perfections do not increase and grow;
Because it does not increase, one does not quickly attain the Way.
Now, knowing the characteristics of all dharmas, one uproots the fundamental six evil dharmas.
Why is it so?
The bodhisattva knows that giving is good, and a stingy mind is not good, and can lead to falling into the poverty of hungry ghosts.
Knowing stinginess and greed to be like this, one still cherishes one's body and becomes attached to worldly pleasures, thus giving rise to stingy thoughts again.
This bodhisattva can give away light things but not heavy things;
He can give away external things but not internal things.

Because of attachment to self and attachment to the recipient, because of grasping at characteristics and attachment to wealth, this breaks the perfection of giving, and although there is giving, it is not pure.
Because this bodhisattva practices in accordance with emptiness, he does not see self, nor does he see worldly pleasures. How can attachment arise to break the perfection of giving?
Question:
If it is because he does not see self and does not see worldly pleasures that he does not break [the perfection of giving], then he should also not see giving. How can he practice giving?
Answer:
Although this bodhisattva does not see giving, he gives with a pure and empty mind, thinking:
This giving is empty and nonexistent, but I give to sentient beings because they need it.
It is like a child who takes dirt as gold and silver, and an elder does not see it as gold and silver, so he gives it to him as he wishes, but in the end there is nothing to give.
The other five dharmas are also like this.
For this reason, although they are the same in emptiness, they destroy stinginess but not giving.
